| Term                     | Definition                                                                 | Applications in Alchemy                                          | Agrippa’s Magical Philosophy                                      |
|--------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Philosopher's Stone      | A legendary substance said to transform base metals into gold and grant immortality. | Central goal of alchemical practice; symbolizes perfection.      | Represents spiritual enlightenment and ultimate knowledge.        |
| Spiritus Mundi           | The "world spirit" or essence that animates all things in the universe.  | Essential for achieving transformations; sought in alchemical operations. | Connects physical and spiritual realms; enables spiritual ascent.  |
| Albedo                   | The second stage of the alchemical process; involves purification and whitening. | Represents purification in the journey towards creating the stone. | Symbolizes the illumination of the soul and mental clarity.       |
| Calcination              | The process of heating a substance to remove impurities and volatile components. | Used to prepare metals for further transformation.               | Represents the destruction of the ego and false beliefs.          |
| Cohobation               | The act of repeatedly distilling a substance to increase its potency.     | Enhances the purity and strength of the material being worked on. | Reflects the iterative nature of spiritual and intellectual growth.|
| Sulphur                  | One of the three primary alchemical principles; associated with soul and spirit. | Integral to the creation of the philosopher's stone; symbolizes combustion and transformation. | Represents the active, fiery aspect of the alchemical process.    |
| Mercury                  | Another primary principle; linked to fluidity, adaptability, and the mind. | Essential for the movement and transformation of substances.     | Symbolizes the intellect and the bridging of spiritual and material worlds. |
| Salt                     | The third principle; represents the body and physical matter.             | Important for creating stability and structure in alchemical processes. | Embodies the material aspect of existence, grounding the spiritual. |
| Anima Mundi              | The "soul of the world"; the life force that connects all living things.  | Essential for understanding the interconnectedness of nature.   | Suggests a divine connection among all beings; a key to mystical knowledge. |
| Tincture                 | A solution containing the essence of a substance, often used in creating the philosopher's stone. | Represents the transformative power of alchemy; essential for achieving results. | Signifies the infusion of spiritual qualities into physical substances. |
| Great Work               | The overall process of alchemical transformation aimed at achieving the philosopher's stone. | Encompasses all operations and practices in alchemy.             | Represents the journey of personal and spiritual transformation.   |
| Hermeticism              | A philosophical and spiritual tradition based on the writings attributed to Hermes Trismegistus. | Influences the understanding of alchemical principles and practices. | Integrates the physical and spiritual realms in pursuit of divine wisdom. |
| Kabbalah                 | A mystical Jewish tradition focused on the interpretation of the Hebrew scriptures and the nature of God. | Provides a symbolic framework for understanding the divine in alchemical practices. | Influences Agrippa’s thought, integrating spiritual and magical elements. |
| Prima Materia            | The original, unrefined substance from which all things are formed.       | Represents the starting point for all alchemical work.          | Symbolizes the potential for transformation and the unity of existence. |
| Microcosm                | The idea that the human being is a small representation of the larger universe. | Reflects the belief in correspondence between the individual and the cosmos. | Encourages the understanding that personal transformation mirrors universal changes. |
